title: 108_hr1800
content: The policy of the United States is to end animal suffering caused by steel-jawed leghold traps by prohibiting their import, export, and interstate shipment, along with fur from animals trapped in such traps. Prohibited acts and penalties are outlined in the legislation. The legislation prohibits importing, exporting, or transporting steel-jawed leghold traps or fur from animals trapped in such traps. Violators face imprisonment or fines. SEC. 3. REWARDS. The Secretary will pay half of the fine to individuals providing information leading to a conviction under this Act. Officers or employees in official capacity are not eligible for rewards. SEC. 4. ENFORCEMENT. The Secretary enforces this Act and its rules, utilizing personnel and facilities from other agencies. Import and export violations are treated as customs law violations. Enforcement authorities can take action, excluding violations under subsection (b). Enforcement authorities under this Act have the power to detain, search, and seize packages suspected of containing articles in violation of the Act. They can also make warrantless arrests for violations committed in their presence or with probable cause, and execute arrest and search warrants. Enforcement authorities have the power to detain, search, and seize packages suspected of violating the Act. They can also make warrantless arrests for violations committed in their presence or with probable cause, and execute arrest and search warrants. Any article in violation of the Act shall be subject to forfeiture to the United States. Enforcement authorities have the power to detain, search, and seize packages suspected of violating the Act. Any article found in violation shall be subject to forfeiture to the United States, with provisions for seizure, forfeiture, and disposition of the property or proceeds. The customs laws of the United States apply to seizures and forfeitures under this Act. Enforcement authorities, including the Secretary of Commerce and the Secretary of the Treasury, have the power to seize and forfeit property under the Act. The Attorney General can seek injunctions against violators, and cooperation among relevant agencies is required for effective enforcement of the Act and its rules. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "article of fur" refers to furskins or articles made from furskins. The term "conventional steel-jawed leghold trap" describes a device designed to capture animals by snapping closed on their limb. The term "customs laws of the United States" refers to laws enforced by the United States Customs Service. "Import" means to bring into the jurisdiction of the United States. The term "import" in the United States Customs Service refers to bringing goods into the jurisdiction of the United States. The term "interstate commerce" is defined in section 10 of title 18, United States Code, and the term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. The Secretary is authorized to create rules for implementing the Act, which will become effective one year after its enactment.
